turns.text: but like you said - how do you quantify peace?

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: or hope?

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: (you = Nate)

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: exactly, it's really difficult to gauge these things

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: so basically - you think that his speeches was just "talking" and that he pulled the wool over the eyes of this distinguished Swedish panel, but that you're too smart for that?

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: haha

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: however, i think that just the reactions to obama being elected seen around the world at the time were quite touching and did mark a new era in hope

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: not in those terms, that's a bit silly

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: well, when it comes down to it - i just think they know that they're doing and i'd trust them more than the average person i find on the street, including myself

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i believe in obama and believe the committee was justified in their choosing- since they chose him as a group- but i believe they placed an amount of pressure on someone who just arrived into the public spotlight

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: without having had the change to place words into action

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: on the other hand

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: "the chance to place words into action"

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: when you're president, words are action

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: i agree with jennifer

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: words become action- yes. healthcare hasnt been revamped yet, but it is coming

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: hopefully!

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: becuase of him

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: sure - it could have been calculated - to hold him accountable and pull him into the international spotlight more - but they still bestowed this honor on him, and it would tarnish their reputation if they awarded it exclusively for this reason - with all the pride they have for their country, i don't think they would do this with what is at stake - although it could have been a factor

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: what presidents promise and what they do are two different categories

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: people wouldbt have a problem with obama being voted prize winner down the road bc they could look back and list the things he put into action (rather than just his precense)

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I hope so

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: Exactly, this is why i'm still not 100% convinced he should have received it

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: right

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: the prize winner should not be looked upon with doubt- has this happened in the past i wonder? so much contracversy and disagreement?

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I'm sure!

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: especially when you're looking at an international award

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i wouldnt marry someone if there was any doubt. lol just a strange analogy.

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: there's always going to be one country that disagrees with an award

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: he was a new comer.. it was too early

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yeah - proly not - but a lot of times there is disagreement, just maybe not as much - the other issue, is that people usually don't pay attention unless it's someone we all have heard of or can relate to - i mean how many people know who won the nobel prize previously?

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: true- maybe the committee wanted people to pay attention to him

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: thats true nate. i can;t honestly say i know much about many of the past recipients; i just let it go

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yeah, that is possible actually - i def. think - on the other hand, he is the U.S. president and is already noticed and scrutinized a lot

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: americans aren't really loved by the world like we'd like to think

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: maybe for the international community though, they learned about him more and will hold him accountable more

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: it was soooo strange of a choice in my mind and i'm sooo out of world news loop hehehe

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: Just looking through some of the previous winners

turns.speaker: lauren

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: she has a long list of amazing achievements

turns.speaker: lauren

turns.text: I feel like Obama's not there (yet)

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: (hopefully yet)

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yeah, americans aren't always loved - so this can fuel disagreement if the arguments are supported

turns.text: oh definitely

turns.speaker: jenniferb

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: like htis

turns.text: i believe too much emphasis was placed on his race, rather then the efforts he made towards peace

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: list of achievements

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: i dont think so - bc his achievements were listed - and i'd argue that race can't be over emphasized, bc it is so important, it's so determining

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: oh i dont look at it that way nicole, but rather emphasis on possibilities he may offer the world with not only his race but his background and list of "wants" for the us and world

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: i agree, but i feel that may have been one of the reasons he was even in consideration for the award.. especially so early in his presidency

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I disagree

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yeah - of course it was a reason

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: he's a symbol

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I think that was of national importance, it shows how far we've come in some ways

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: certainly a symbol

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: he has made history in that respect

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: but internationally, not really

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: i disagree

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: people around the world were touched by his election

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I think that's more about who he is, than what color his skin happens to be

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: he's an amazing, powerful speaker

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: and a force for change

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: it shows how far america has come in history, what does that have to do with world peace

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text:
no - it has international consequences - to see someone ascend the social structure from such a poor, victimized segment of the population - all the way to the presidency - and talk about things like cooperation and working t!
 ogether, that sets a precedent for his presidency and gives other nations a reason to hope for the U.S.'s cooperation

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i wonder why they dont release nominees until 50 yrs later

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: Obama was neither poor or victimized though

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: exactly, nate

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: actually , he was very poor

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: he's no better a representative of that than I would be a representative of a homeless person

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: he was considered middle class growing up and went to Harvard

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: and how many black people do you know who are wealthy? not many - i mean the average income for a black individual is a joke compared to what it is for a white, that's just a fact

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: you can't argue that

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I'm not arguing racism

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I'm arguing Obama as an "everyman"

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: no president ever, as far I'm concerned, has been an "everyman"

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: his family didn't have any money - they basically had nothing, some intellect - but no money

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: if they were, they wouldn't have the money to get elected

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: or the time away from work

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: he wasn't poor

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: he had money all his life

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: hence his presidency

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: well - why don't you read a paragraph biography on the early life of our president - the guy was lower class, maybe lower middle class - that's a sharp contrast from any

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: other president i can think of , especially in modern history

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i do see him as differetn from past presidents- hence a feeling of hope for the country

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: economically-wise

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: anyone can do anything in this country

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: their family couldn't afford to send him to college - so that's quite a bit different than someone with blue blood who is just born and does nothing

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: if circumstance are allowing overall

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: can we focus on the peace prize

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: so his symbolism got him the prize- are we in agreement on this bit?

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: "anyone can do anything in this country" - that's the most naive statement i've heard in a long time

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: right - why don't we just go out and become VPs at bank of america

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I disagree with that Jennifer

turns.speaker: jenniferb

turns.text: anbody cannot do anything in this country!

turns.text: well, since we came to a standstill

turns.speaker: jenniferb

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: do we have to come to some conclusion? or can we just agree to disagree?

turns.speaker: lauren

turns.text: mmhmm

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: lol

turns.text: my opinion hasn't swayed; i still am not convinced, but i do think this is quite the interesting topic

turns.speaker: Nicole

turns.speaker: jenniferb

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: i don't think this chat worked out as planned

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: well, I think the idea is more to study the dynamics of the chat

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: not for us to overthrow the Nobel committee

turns.speaker: nate

turns.text: agreed, Nate

turns.text: i need health insurance! haha!

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: same

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: oh, yeah - inrid bettencourt - a lot of personal and political courage to fight graft - her life was in the balance with drug cartels , yet she advocated for groups that were being exploited - she easily could have

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: just taken the bribes and kickbacks the cartels offered

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i could just make a comment about how people didnt like my earlier comment- i believe that if people dont think or behave positively, there is no chance for overcoming obstacles or challenges- i just like to believe that things are possible even if not at arms length.

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: wish the world was like that

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: what comment was that Jennifer?

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: ;) gotta try even if i dont see it happen

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: about my view on people can do anything

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yes, i agree - we can write our own destiny, be captain of our own fait - we have control, and this is an appealing idea - but with someone like Obama or nearly most people for that matter - you're limited by the place you are in society at the time of your birth, people usually don't climb much higher

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i have personal experience there- or witnessed rather- and it can be remarkable

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: fate *

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: your fate is yours

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: lol

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: i mean you can improve your lot and position , for sure - countless people do - but usually you're not going to go from middle to upper class and be able to touch all these lives

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: i dont disagree, life is tough

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: i agree nate. while we try to think that we live in a classless society, we don't. it's much more difficult to increase your status when u start from the bottom

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: I think our society has a few structures built in to try and level the playing field

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: change has occurred though, and its because the people achieved what most people believed to be impossible

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: although it's sort of like putting bandaids on a gushing wound

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: the underlying structure is still pretty hard to overcome

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: structure for sure- the foundation is difficult to change even if one or two are able

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yeah - there are deep structural factors

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: our society doesn't really enable equal opportunity for all, no matter the structures that are present

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: structural factors like poverty and inequality - but it reflects really well on the U.S. - that someone succeeded like this, and that it gave hope to immigrants and people looking for a more peaceful, prosperous, productive life coming to American soil

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: i agree

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: yes- public figures make differences

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: well - i mean this bettencourt lady worked to stop widespread corruption in south america -

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: so this goes a long way in bringing about peace - whereas most other people succumb to the pressure and the threats on their life in this region of south america where mass killings and kidnappings are supposedly common place for anyone who opposes the cartels, although this could be sensationalized too - i dont really know for sure

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: she said she wants to become the president of Columbia

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: so maybe we'll be seeing more of her

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: hope so

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: it does show true integrity to oppose such powerful groups that could really murder you and get away with it. i hope we do here more about her

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: are we nominating her for the peace prize?

turns.speaker: jenniferb
turns.text: thanks for bringing up

turns.speaker: nate
turns.text: yeah, hopefuly she stays alive too - i mean it proly sounds ridiculous - but it almost sounds like politicians like her are really targeted by the opposition and sometimes even assassinated bc they want to change things too much and stop the killings

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: makes sense

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: if killing is the tool of choice

turns.speaker: Farina
turns.text: oh yeah nate. this isn't ridiculous at all, it happens all over the world and someone that rises up and stands against such power is powerful him/herself

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: when someone stands in your way, or cries out too loud, you kill them

turns.speaker: Nicole
turns.text: soo the chats almost coming to a end: so lets sum up

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: Obama:

turns.speaker: nate

turns.speaker: lauren
turns.text: all against, except 1 for
